page.title: 17HUTTON ESTATE - BUILDINGS
page.content:
Most farms have a traditional core of original buildings with sandstone and cobble walls roofed with either sandstone or a combination of green and grey ordinary slates. In addition many have an outlying fringe dating from the early 1900's, with black or red painted corrugated steel sheeted pole barns, put up under the auspices of Mr S Fraser, the then agent.
In the 1960's and 1970's Lord Inglewood and the agents Messrs D & J Cowen, and Mr A McElwee, instituted a programme of new buildings appropriate for current farming techniques, built with mainly steel frames and rendered block walls, with asbestos or timber cladding and asbestos roofs. The building at Home Farm won a C.L.A. award in 1975.
